metadata.titleEn: Daily soil moisture and temprature in the edge of the Tibetan Plateau in 2018.7-2019.7
metadata.description: Soil temperature and moisture are valuable in agriculture, hydrology, meteorology. This daily soil moisture and temperature data set (2018.7-2019.7) is averaged from hourly measurement. Data observation site are located over Gaizi river basin in the Pamirs Plateau ,and HuangShuiHe river in the northeast Tibetan Plateau, the Yarlung zangbo river basin in the southern Tibetan Plateau.The instrument used are  ECH2O - EC5 and 5TM. GaiZi soil temperature is measured using TR129 probe. Data are collected from 21 measurement sites. The data set also includes site location, soil texture, environmental attribute data. The depths of the measurement are 10, 40, 80 and 120 cm below surface. This data can be used to verify land surface model.
metadata.instructions: Data are saved in an excel file (Daily_Smoothed_SM_ST.xlsx). There are two sheets. The first is soil temperature (ST_daily), the second is soil moisture (SM_daily). Columns are stations and soil layers, raws are times. The first raw is the site and layer title, the first column is daily time series. Data meta file is in a word document named Site_info.docx.

background: Over the past decades, warming climate has resulted in the degradation of frozen soil manifested primarily by increasing ground temperature, decreasing seasonally frozen soil depth, increasing depth of active layer thickness, thinning permafrost layer, increasing fragmentation of permafrost soil, and disappearing of permafrost islands. Frozen soil degradation has exerted significant influences in ecosystem, climate, hydrology, sediment transport and infrastructure in the polar regions, the Tibetan Plateau (TP) and other cold regions. About 99% of the Tibetan Plateau (TP) is covered by frozen soils and degradation of frozen soils will certainly impact TP's ecosystems. Frozen soil usually underlies alpine ecosystem. Frozen soil degradation due to global warming affects alpine ecosystem. The degradation of frozen soil has affected alpine meadow and alpine steppe on the plateau. However, exactly how the degradation has affected alpine grassland is still a highly debated topic.
research objective: Here, we investigate decadal changes of frozen soils and net primary productivity (NPP, representing vegetation) in the degraded frozen soil zones and the TP during 1982–2014 and 2015–2100 using a dynamic vegetation model, historical records and the latest CMIP6 projections, as well as observation-based soil temperature thresholds. This study examines the frozen soil degradation and net primary productivity (NPP) of plants that is associated with the degradation in 1982–2014 and 2015–2100.
challenges: Clearly, contradictory findings from point based and large-scale studies do not help design effective ecosystem conservation policies on the TP. These recent studies only examined static soil types (e.g., permafrost vs. non-permafrost soils specifically) during their study periods and did not show how the entire biomass changed dynamically with permafrost soil degradation over the time.
methods: The Lunds-Postdam-Jena Dynamic Global Vegetation Model (LPJ) that has been widely applied globally was used in this study. The model spatial resolution was set at 0.25° in this study and there were 3,978 cells on the TP. The simulation time spanned from 1957 to 2020. The model was warmed up by running iteratively from 1957 to 1986 for 1,000 yr in order to achieve dynamic vegetation equilibrium following Cuo et al. (2016) and Sitch et al. (2003), and then the 1957 model state was used as the initial condition for the subsequent 1957–2020 simulation period.
dataset: Observed daily temperature and precipitation were from the China Meteorological Administration (CMA, http://data.cma.cn/), and were gridded onto the 0.25° model grid following the procedures described in Cuo et al. (2013) before being aggregated to monthly values. Two permafrost soil maps compiled by Ran and Li (2000) and Zou et al. (2017), respectively, were used to identify frozen soil zone and its changes on the TP. The map by Zou et al. (2017), at 0.01° spatial resolution, was based on soil temperature, soil moisture and bulk density observed during 2009–2014, as well as MODIS land surface temperature and a widely used model that calculates temperature at the top of permafrost. In total, observations from 125 boreholes and 199 soil pits during 2009–2014 on the plateau were used by Zou et al. (2017). In this study, we used the map by Ran and Li (2000) at 0.0083° spatial resolution and referred to it as RL1982 to represent the early 1980s’ conditions (Nan et al., 2002, also used measurements that were originally published in 1982).
findings: In 1982–2014, degraded permafrost soil zones were in the range of 316,975–455,402 km2, with mean annual NPP staying around 84.9 gCm−2 and annual NPP showing a significant reduction at −1.71 gCm−2/year due primarily to warming air. Seasonally frozen soil also degraded by 15,636 km2 in the southeast TP, with mean annual NPP staying around 620.0 gCm−2 and annual NPP showing a significant increase at 11.00 gCm−2/year. In the future, frozen soil continues to degrade and the degradation accelerates toward the end of the century such that only 2.7% of permafrost soil in 2014 is left by 2080–2100 under the shared socioeconomic pathway SSP5-8.5. Mean annual NPP in the permafrost soil degraded zones in 2015–2100 is about half of that for 1982–2014, with spatially mixed decrease and increase trends in the near-, mid-, and long-term periods. Over the seasonally frozen soil degraded zones and the entire TP, more positive than negative annual NPP changes are seen in 2015–2100, especially in the southeast of the TP, due to improved growing conditions and the expansion of primarily subtropical and temperate scrubland. The study finds that as permafrost soil degrades, alpine meadow and steppe NPP decreases significantly in 1982–2014. In the future, permafrost soil continues to degrade in line with increasing CO2 emission. However, NPP associated with the permafrost soil degradation shows little change in the future. On the other hand, although seasonally frozen soil degrades in both the historical and future periods, the associated NPP mostly increases in both periods across the plateau.

background: Frozen soil properties and thermohydraulic processes are still not fully understood due to lack of in-situ measurements, especially in the high altitudes and high latitudes (HAHL). Sand and silt are the dominant soil particles and clay is less than 10% at the sites. Existing and widely used soil products underestimates (significantly overestimates) sand (clay) content on the TP which raises the uncertainty in the thermohydraulic parameters derived from these products. Diurnal soil moisture and temperature variations are seen only above 40 cm, but seasonal variations occur down to 120 cm due to the soil memory effect. Seasonally frozen soil and permafrost soil show different freezing and melting processes. Dry soil features greater soil temperature temporal variability and deeper maximum frozen depth than wet soil. Zero curtain occurs in both dry and wet soil, and displays high (low) frequency but short (long) duration at 10 (80) cm that vary spatially. Moisture depression exists in seasonally frozen soil and is determined by the initial soil moisture and temperature gradient strength. The strong thermohydraulic coupling existed in cold season collapses in warm season. Soil moisture exhibits higher spatiotemporal variability than soil temperature. Permafrost and seasonally frozen soils have complex thermohydraulic properties and they are widely distributed in the high altitudes and high latitudes (HAHL), accounting for about 22% and 51% of the land in the Northern Hemisphere, respectively. Since soil has up to a season-long memory of water and heat, soil heat and water conditions can be useful for sub-seasonal to seasonal climate forecasts. Soil moisture anomaly can induce feedbacks that influence precipitation processes over land in the monsoon region. High spatiotemporal-resolution in-situ measurements of soil temperature and moisture in the HAHL are the key to reveal soil thermohydraulic processes such as freezing and thawing and enhance our understanding of soil thermohydraulic theory which is critical for developing and improving the parameterization of the thermohydraulic process in numerical models. However, there are still significant challenges faced by researchers in the HAHL. One is the lack of proper understanding of physical processes. Another one is the large uncertainties in model parameterization for accurately simulating the dynamic freeze-thaw processes.
research objective: The objective of this study is two-fold: 1) to investigate the spatiotemporal characteristics of soil texture and thermohydraulic processes in the frozen soil on the TP; and 2) to understand the differences in soil moisture and temperature behavior under various climate conditions and the possible mechanisms behind the differences.
challenges: On the other hand, in the northeast region, only DT is examined and this is clearly not enough and more sites and more observations are needed to fully represent the spatial patterns of soil moisture and temperature there. Additional multi-year observations of soil moisture and temperature at deeper depths and higher-resolution layers (more levels) will certainly enable the robust and in-depth analyses of the soil thermohydraulic process on the TP.
methods: Based on hourly measurements at 10, 40, 80 and 120 cm depths at 21 sites in the west, south and northeast regions of the Tibetan Plateau (TP) during July 2018 - July 2019, we examined soil particles, spatiotemporal variations of soil thermohydraulic processes and their connections with environmental factors to reveal the heterogenous frozen soil properties on the TP. Soil samples were collected at all sites in four layers whenever possible to determine clay, silt and sand contents and soil texture using the USDA soil textural triangle diagram. The procedure was conducted in laboratory in the following steps: 1) drying soil samples in room temperature, 2) sieving soil samples through 2-mm-mesh sieves, 3) removing organic content by adding 30% H2O2 solution and carbonate by using 10% HCl solution, and 4) using the Malvern laser particle size analyzer (Mastersizer 3000) to determine the soil particle sizes.
dataset: Based on hourly measurements at 10, 40, 80 and 120 cm depths at 21 sites in the west, south and northeast regions of the Tibetan Plateau (TP) during July 2018 - July 2019. We obtained measured soil particle contents at various locations on the TP (referred to as MSST) including the 21 LC sites, as well as Haibei, Maqu, Zoige, Madoi, Beiluhe, Chalaping, Naqu and Ngari from Su et al. (2011, 2013), Dente et al. (2012), Van der Velde et al. (2012), Yang et al. (2013), Zeng et al. (2016), Pan et al. (2017), Fang et al. (2018), Luo et al. (2018a), Yi et al. (2018), and Dai et al. (2019) for a collective examination.
findings: These findings fill the knowledge gaps in the soil thermohydraulic processes in the HAHL, and improve the understanding of frozen soil properties and heat-water coupling processes in soil in the HAHL. The study will benefit the Earth system model development and improve the quality of soil temperature and moisture assimilation and remote sensing products in the HAHL.

Definition.Question: What does 'soil thermohydraulic processes' mean in the context of frozen soil research on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Soil thermohydraulic processes refer to the interactions and behaviors of soil temperature and moisture, including freezing and thawing processes, in frozen soil environments. These processes are influenced by soil texture, climate conditions, and the soil's ability to retain heat and moisture over time, which are critical for understanding the dynamics of frozen soil properties and the impact on ecosystems in high altitudes and high latitudes.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'dynamic vegetation model' in assessing frozen soil degradation and its impact on net primary productivity?
Definition.Answer: A dynamic vegetation model, such as the Lunds-Postdam-Jena Dynamic Global Vegetation Model (LPJ), simulates the interactions between vegetation and climate over time. In the context of frozen soil degradation, it helps assess changes in net primary productivity (NPP) by modeling how vegetation responds to environmental changes, including soil temperature and moisture variations, across different time periods and climate scenarios on the Tibetan Plateau.

Definition.Question: What does 'zero curtain' phenomenon signify in soil temperature analysis within frozen soil studies?
Definition.Answer: The 'zero curtain' phenomenon refers to the period during which soil temperature remains near the freezing point despite ongoing heat exchange processes. It occurs in both dry and wet soil and is characterized by high frequency and short duration at shallower depths (e.g., 10 cm) and low frequency and long duration at deeper depths (e.g., 80 cm). This phenomenon is important for understanding the thermal properties of frozen soil and its implications for soil moisture and temperature dynamics.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of hourly measurements at multiple soil depths compare to other data collection methods in capturing soil thermohydraulic processes on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Hourly measurements at various depths (10, 40, 80, and 120 cm) allow for detailed spatiotemporal analysis of soil thermohydraulic processes, revealing heterogeneous frozen soil properties. This method provides high-resolution data that can uncover diurnal and seasonal variations not captured by less frequent sampling methods.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges faced in simulating dynamic freeze-thaw processes differ from those encountered in static soil type studies on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Simulating dynamic freeze-thaw processes is challenged by large uncertainties in model parameterization and a lack of understanding of physical processes, whereas static soil type studies are limited by their inability to show dynamic changes in biomass and permafrost soil degradation. Both require more extensive data collection for improved accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying factors can be inferred from the spatial and temporal variations in soil temperature and moisture data at different depths in frozen soil areas?
Interpretation.Answer: The variations in soil temperature and moisture at different depths suggest complex thermohydraulic properties of frozen soils, influenced by soil texture, climate conditions, and soil memory effects. Diurnal variations above 40 cm and seasonal variations down to 120 cm indicate a significant impact of initial soil moisture and temperature gradients on freezing and thawing processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the observed variation in soil temperature and moisture at different depths in the Tibetan Plateau's frozen soil regions during data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The observed variation in soil temperature and moisture at different depths in the Tibetan Plateau's frozen soil regions is caused by the soil memory effect, where diurnal variations occur only above 40 cm, but seasonal variations are seen down to 120 cm. This is due to the different freezing and melting processes in seasonally frozen soil and permafrost soil, as well as the soil's thermohydraulic properties.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a significant challenge in understanding the thermohydraulic processes in frozen soils on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: There is a significant challenge in understanding the thermohydraulic processes in frozen soils on the Tibetan Plateau due to the lack of high spatiotemporal-resolution in-situ measurements, which are crucial for revealing soil thermohydraulic processes such as freezing and thawing. Additionally, existing soil products tend to underestimate sand content and overestimate clay content, raising uncertainties in thermohydraulic parameter derivation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the degradation of permafrost soil and changes in net primary productivity on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The degradation of permafrost soil and changes in net primary productivity on the Tibetan Plateau are primarily caused by warming climate conditions, which increase ground temperature, decrease seasonally frozen soil depth, and lead to the fragmentation of permafrost soil. These changes are further influenced by the increase in CO2 emissions and improved growing conditions that affect the spatial distribution of vegetation.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the use of in-situ measurements at high altitudes and latitudes impact the understanding of soil thermohydraulic processes and model parameterization?
Causal Consequence.Answer: In-situ measurements at high altitudes and latitudes are crucial for understanding soil thermohydraulic processes because they provide high spatiotemporal-resolution data that reveal freezing and thawing processes. This understanding is essential for improving model parameterizations, which currently face significant uncertainties in accurately simulating dynamic freeze-thaw processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using both observational data and dynamic vegetation models on understanding the degradation of frozen soils and net primary productivity (NPP) in the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using both observational data and dynamic vegetation models allows for a comprehensive examination of frozen soil degradation and its impact on net primary productivity (NPP) over time. This combined approach helps in understanding the spatially mixed trends in NPP changes and provides insights into the future degradation of permafrost and seasonally frozen soils, thus informing potential ecosystem conservation strategies.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to investigate the spatiotemporal characteristics of soil texture and thermohydraulic processes in frozen soil on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Investigating these characteristics is crucial for understanding the thermohydraulic properties of permafrost and seasonally frozen soils, which can improve Earth system model development and enhance the quality of soil temperature and moisture assimilation and remote sensing products.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to measure and average soil temperature and moisture on a daily basis in permafrost regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Daily soil temperature and moisture measurements are obtained by averaging hourly observations over a 24-hour period using instruments like the ECH2O-EC5 and 5TM. The data collection involves multiple depths at 10, 40, 80, and 120 centimeters across 21 sites located in various river basins.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is soil texture analyzed in high-altitude frozen soil regions, and what are the steps to prepare soil samples for analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil texture is analyzed using the USDA soil textural triangle diagram. The procedure involves drying soil samples at room temperature, sieving them through 2-mm mesh sieves, removing organic content with 30% H2O2 solution, and using 10% HCl solution to remove carbonate. Finally, a Malvern laser particle size analyzer is used to determine the soil particle sizes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed for mapping and monitoring changes in frozen soil zones on the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Mapping and monitoring changes in frozen soil zones involve using historical records, soil temperature thresholds, and dynamic vegetation models like the Lunds-Postdam-Jena Dynamic Global Vegetation Model (LPJ) with a spatial resolution of 0.25°. The process includes using permafrost soil maps and soil data from boreholes and soil pits, integrating them with MODIS land surface temperature data.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the collection of detailed soil temperature and moisture data in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of instruments such as ECH2O-EC5 and 5TM for soil moisture and temperature observation, as well as TR129 probes for soil temperature, enables detailed data collection in the Tibetan Plateau. Moreover, the Malvern laser particle size analyzer (Mastersizer 3000) is used for soil texture analysis.

Enablement.Question: How do specific data collection methods enhance the understanding of soil thermohydraulic processes in frozen soil regions?
Enablement.Answer: Hourly measurements at various depths (10, 40, 80, and 120 cm) at multiple sites provide insights into soil thermohydraulic processes by capturing diurnal and seasonal variations, which are critical for understanding the freezing and thawing processes in frozen soil regions.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are encountered in expanding datasets for soil moisture and temperature in remote high-altitude locations, and how can they be addressed?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include the lack of in-situ measurements and the need for more observation sites to fully represent spatial patterns. Addressing these challenges involves collecting multi-year observations at deeper depths and adding more high-resolution layers to enable robust analyses.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in accurately capturing the thermohydraulic properties of frozen soils in high-altitude regions?
Expectation.Answer: Frozen soil properties and thermohydraulic processes are not fully understood due to a lack of in-situ measurements, especially in high altitudes and high latitudes. The existing soil products may underestimate or overestimate certain soil particle contents, raising uncertainty in derived thermohydraulic parameters.

Expectation.Question: What factors could contribute to the difficulties in obtaining consistent data on soil moisture and temperature at various depths in the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Difficulties arise from the high spatiotemporal variability of soil moisture compared to soil temperature, and the complex freezing and melting processes that differ between seasonally frozen and permafrost soils. Additionally, the region's challenging environment and lack of multi-year observations at deeper depths and higher-resolution layers contribute to the data collection challenges.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be discrepancies between point-based studies and large-scale analyses of frozen soil degradation and its effects on ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Contradictory findings from point-based and large-scale studies do not help in designing effective ecosystem conservation policies. Recent studies often examine static soil types without showing dynamic changes in biomass due to permafrost soil degradation over time, leading to discrepancies in findings.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using the Lunds-Postdam-Jena Dynamic Global Vegetation Model (LPJ) in capturing the decadal changes of frozen soils and net primary productivity in the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: The LPJ model, with its global application and spatial resolution set at 0.25°, offers a structured approach to simulating vegetation dynamics. Its effectiveness in the Tibetan Plateau context is underscored by its ability to capture historical and future changes in frozen soils and NPP, as evidenced by the significant findings from 1982-2014 and projections to 2100. However, challenges remain in reconciling point-based and large-scale discrepancies and refining model parameterization for dynamic soil processes.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how researchers can accurately measure soil temperature and moisture at different depths in frozen soil regions.
Assertion.Answer: Researchers use instruments like ECH2O-EC5, 5TM, and TR129 probes to measure soil temperature and moisture at various depths. Observations are conducted hourly and averaged to daily values for analysis.

Assertion.Question: I'm unclear about the challenges faced in understanding the thermohydraulic processes of frozen soils in high-altitude regions.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include a lack of in-situ measurements, large uncertainties in model parameterization, and limited understanding of physical processes, especially regarding the dynamic freeze-thaw processes and soil texture variations.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how datasets of soil characteristics are compiled and verified for regions like the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets are compiled from hourly measurements at multiple sites and include soil particle content analysis using techniques like the Malvern laser particle size analyzer. Additional data is gathered from previous studies to collectively examine soil properties.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used for soil temperature and moisture in the Tibetan Plateau, including any instruments and techniques applied.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection methods for soil temperature and moisture in the Tibetan Plateau involved using ECH2O-EC5 and 5TM instruments for general observations, and TR129 probes specifically for soil temperature in the Geyzi River Basin. Observations were taken hourly at depths of 10, 40, 80, and 120 cm across 21 sites, and these hourly measurements were averaged over 24 hours to obtain daily data. Soil samples were used to determine soil texture by drying, sieving, removing organic content and carbonates, and analyzing particle sizes using a Malvern laser particle size analyzer.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that could complement the existing soil temperature and moisture observations on the Tibetan Plateau to enhance research on frozen soil properties and processes.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets that could complement existing observations include historical soil temperature and moisture records, additional permafrost soil maps with high spatial resolution, and climate data such as daily temperature and precipitation from the China Meteorological Administration. These could be used to validate models and provide broader context for understanding frozen soil properties and processes in the Tibetan Plateau.
